20c00517dd564669fc026f31b1fecc21dbe1db21.title: Stanford’s Pulitzer Winner Jack Rakove on American Independence
20c00517dd564669fc026f31b1fecc21dbe1db21.description:
In this week’s episode of The Learning Curve, co-hosts Alisha Searcy and Massachusetts civics teacher Kelley Brown interview Pulitzer Prize-winning historian Jack Rakove, Coe Professor Emeritus at Stanford University. Prof. Rakove explores the origins of the American Revolution and U.S. Constitution through the lives of the nation’s Founding Era figures. Reflecting on young John Adams’ vivid depiction of his schoolhouse in colonial Massachusetts, Rakove offers context for the political and social landscape of the 18th-century America.

The post Stanford’s Pulitzer Winner Jack Rakove on American Independence appeared first on Pioneer Institute.

4397d45805633839103771afc1f3eaf168ee5ade.title: Press Release – HJ 6007: “one of the worst ideas” passed by the General Assembly
4397d45805633839103771afc1f3eaf168ee5ade.description:
The Virginia Institute for Public Policy has expressed concern over HJ6007, a proposed amendment to Virginia’s Constitution that would alter the state’s current redistricting process. The Institute emphasized that Virginia voters approved a bipartisan approach in 2020 to ensure fair and transparent elections for all citizens. Citing constitutional and procedural issues surrounding HJ6007, the Institute encourages lawmakers to uphold established safeguards that protect the integrity and balance of Virginia’s electoral system.

95b5efe8383a08071bde2fef2271171f2b64c9f7.title: State Report Card on Telehealth Reform: Incremental Progress in 2025 Leaves Many States Unprepared for Rural Health Transformation Funding
95b5efe8383a08071bde2fef2271171f2b64c9f7.description:
Boston, Mass – A new report from the Cicero Institute and Pioneer Institute finds that while state legislatures remained active on telehealth policy in 2025, most states made only incremental progress toward modern, patient-centered telehealth systems. With the passage of the One Big Beautiful Bill and its $50 billion Rural Health Transformation Program, states now face growing pressure to modernize outdated telehealth laws or risk falling behind in access, affordability, and federal funding competitiveness.

The post State Report Card on Telehealth Reform: Incremental Progress in 2025 Leaves Many States Unprepared for Rural Health Transformation Funding appeared first on Pioneer Institute.

d18e6580b07cf1b19983a170d80d096179204732.description:
On Jan. 5, 1776, New Hampshire became the first self-governing British colony in North America. That astonishing decision, made 250 years ago this week, deserved a bigger celebration than it received.  After a quarter of a millennium, Americans have become accustomed to thinking that self-government is normal. It isn’t. Achieving it in 1776 was extraordinary. […]

bd1ce0a48d2f2c9ff632c9997b3a2bd647071fbc.description:

9f05d0b104f9da8f0e082e987402cafd7bf68b50.title: Session Preview: No Shutdown Rule
9f05d0b104f9da8f0e082e987402cafd7bf68b50.description:
Iowa currently lacks a clear process to prevent a state government shutdown if a budget is not passed on time, creating uncertainty for taxpayers and essential services. A budget-continuation, or “no shutdown,” rule would ensure government operations continue by temporarily extending the prior year’s budget during impasses or emergencies. Adopting such a rule would promote stability, limit political brinkmanship, and align Iowa with best practices already used in other states. Last year, Iowans once again watched Washington struggle through another federal government shutdown.

The post Session Preview: No Shutdown Rule appeared first on ITR Foundation.
